TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}

S.FORM: izua marekaka a maḍusa, neka nu kina, neka nu kama, mapułu tiamadju.
izoa marekaka a madrosa, neka no kina, neka no kama, mapoljo tiamadjo.
S.TRANSL: There were two children with no mother or father, all on their own.
They went to the fields.
There was Granny Vuluvulung.
The children went over to her.

S.FORM: "pai ku tulu-aw mun tua sika sengsengan."
"pai ko tolo-aw mon toa sika sengsengan."
S.TRANSL: She said: “Right, I’ll teach you how to work the fields.”
They went off home.
Next day she said: “Siblings, go and get some poles.”
They went to find some poles.

S.FORM: i umaq a vuvu a tsemalitsalis.
i omaq a vovo a cemalicalis.
S.TRANSL: Grandmother stayed in the house making thread.

S.FORM: ka mangtjez a marekaka a nakitatuzungan, "vuvu, mavatsuvatsuk anga qaliqali, vuvu."
ka mangtjez a marekaka a nakitatozongan, "vovo, mavacovacok anga qaliqali, vovo."
S.TRANSL: When the children came back after finding some poles, they said: “Grandmother, other people are clearing their land for planting.”
“Be quiet.
What if they are clearing the land?
It’s up to them.

S.FORM: sa-u, ła qunu, kimu tua tsuqelał."
sa-o, lja qono, kimo toa coqelalj."
S.TRANSL: Go and find some bones, children.”

S.FORM: vaik a masi kałaudjul; łemułu tua tsuqelał.
vaik a masi kaljaodjol; ljemoljo toa coqelalj.
S.TRANSL: They went off with a basket and picked up some bones.
“Is that enough, grandmother?”
“It’s not enough yet;
go and get some more.”
“Grandmother, what are you going to do with the thread you’re making?”
“Nothing.

S.FORM: sa-u, kimu tua vat nua łui."
sa-o, kimo toa vat noa ljoi."
S.TRANSL: Go and find some gourd seeds.”

S.FORM: ka makatsalis anga ti sa Vuluvulung, "ari anga, ła qunu, savavua-i.
ka makacalis anga ti sa Volovolong, "ari anga, lja qono, savavoa-i.
S.TRANSL: When Granny Vuluvulung had finished making thread, she said: “Right, children, let’s go to the fields.

S.FORM: katsu a tatuzungan katua tsuqelał katua vat nua łui."
kaco a tatozongan katoa coqelalj katoa vat noa ljoi."
S.TRANSL: Take the poles, bones and gourd seeds.”

S.FORM: ka zemuker i vavua, "sa-u, ła qunu, tsektsekan tsa tatuzungan."
ka zemoker i vavoa, "sa-o, lja qono, cekcekan ca tatozongan."
S.TRANSL: When they got to the fields, she said: “Children, go and stick the poles in the ground.

S.FORM: ka sinitsektsek anga, sipaqadjay a tsalis pakipalinguł, sa viłviłen ni sa Vuluvulung.
ka sinicekcek anga, sipaqadjay a calis pakipalingolj, sa viljviljen ni sa Volovolong.
S.TRANSL: When they were stuck in, Granny Vuluvulung tied them with the thread all round and pulled it tight.
“It would be good if the work were all done,” they said.
So it was all done.

S.FORM: "sa-u, taleman tsa tsuqelał katua vat nua łui.
"sa-o, taleman ca coqelalj katoa vat noa ljoi.
S.TRANSL: “Go and plant the bones and the gourd seeds.

S.FORM: azua tsuqelał taleman pakateku nu upu; azua łui pakavavaw nu upu."
azoa coqelalj taleman pakateko no opo; azoa ljoi pakavavaw no opo."
S.TRANSL: Plant the bones below the terrace wall, and the gourds above it.”

S.FORM: qau vaik tiamadju a sema umaq.
qao vaik tiamadjo a sema omaq.
S.TRANSL: Then they went home.

S.FORM: "sa-u, łiłavu a tja quma, nuki kemudakudanga."
"sa-o, ljiljavo a tja qoma, noki kemodakodanga."
S.TRANSL: “Go and look at our field, to see how it’s getting on.”
They went to have a look.

S.FORM: ka mangtjez i umaq, "kemudakudanga, ła qunu?"
ka mangtjez i omaq, "kemodakodanga, lja qono?"
S.TRANSL: When they got home, she asked: “How is it, children?”
“There are beginning to be cracks in the ground, grandmother.
Other people’s millet is ripe.”
“What? What if it is ripe?”
They went to the fields.
“Take a pestle and mortar.”

S.FORM: ka zemker i vavua, "sa-u patsunu, ła qunu.
ka zemker i vavoa, "sa-o pacono, lja qono.
S.TRANSL: When they got to the fields, she said: “Children, go and look.
If there is anything grunting, pick it up.”
The bones had become pigs,
and the gourds had become millet.

S.FORM: tsemułu tiamadju; san qavay i vavua.
cemoljo tiamadjo; san qavay i vavoa.
S.TRANSL: They butchered the pigs, and made millet dumplings there in the fields.

S.FORM: "sa-u, alapu a penułat a vangał nua łui a pasa tapaw.
"sa-o, alapo a penoljat a vangalj noa ljoi a pasa tapaw.
S.TRANSL: “Go and put all the produce of the gourds in the shed,

S.FORM: sa nu sutsevełen a qatsang a penułat.
sa no soceveljen a qacang a penoljat.
S.TRANSL: and dig out all the pigs.”

S.FORM: ari vaiki anga, ła qunu, a sema umaq.
ari vaiki anga, lja qono, a sema omaq.
S.TRANSL: (Later she said:) “Come on, children, let’s go home.
Carry the gourds on your backs.”

S.FORM: sa azua qatsang uaguin a pasa umaq.
sa azoa qacang oagoin a pasa omaq.
S.TRANSL: And they drove the pigs home.

S.FORM: ka zemuker i umaq, "sa-u katsu, ła qunu, sa nu kula sa nu qavuvung a kivala."
ka zemoker i omaq, "sa-o kaco, lja qono, sa no kola sa no qavovong a kivala."
S.TRANSL: When they got home, she said: “Off you go, children, take legs and hearts (from the butchered pigs) and go where you like.”

S.FORM: ka patsun a qaliqali, "ii, puvuvu tua qaqa," aya qaliqali.
ka pacon a qaliqali, "ii, povovo toa qaqa," aya qaliqali.
S.TRANSL: When other people saw them, they said: “Ha ha, they’ve got a crow for a grandmother.”

S.FORM: qau vaik a pasemalaw tua vuvu.
qao vaik a pasemalaw toa vovo.
S.TRANSL: The children went and told the grandmother:

S.FORM: "'ii, puvuvu tua qaqa,' aya qaliqali, vuvu."
"'ii, povovo toa qaqa,' aya qaliqali, vovo."
S.TRANSL: “Grandmother, other people say: ‘Ha ha, they’ve got a crow for a grandmother.’”
“What if people say that?”
They went out again.
People said: “Ha ha, they’ve got a crow for a grandmother.”
They went home.

S.FORM: "'ii, puvuvu tua qaqa,' aya qaliqali," aya uta.
"'ii, povovo toa qaqa,' aya qaliqali," aya ota.
S.TRANSL: Again they said: “People say: ‘Haha, they’ve got a crow for a grandmother.’”

S.FORM: "ui, uri vaik aken nu maya," sa "qaqa," aya timadju a vaik.
"oi, ori vaik aken no maya," sa "qaqa," aya timadjo a vaik.
S.TRANSL: “All right, in that case I’m off.”So she said “Caw caw,” and went off.
When she had gone she whistled:
“May the food and pigs vanish.”
Then there was nothing left.

S.FORM: a matsułanga tiamadju a tsemikel, saka izuanga a qemauqaung.
a macoljanga tiamadjo a cemikel, saka izoanga a qemaoqaong.
S.TRANSL: They were back to being hungry, and they just cried.

S.FORM: "kavala ka izuanan ti vuvu; inika tjen a kipaulaula tua tja kanen," aya tiamadju a kinemnem, ka vaik anga ti sa Vuluvulung.
"kavala ka izoanan ti vovo; inika tjen a kipaolaola toa tja kanen," aya tiamadjo a kinemnem, ka vaik anga ti sa Volovolong.
S.TRANSL: “If only grandmother was still here. Then we wouldn’t be in trouble over our food,” they thought, when Granny Vuluvulung had gone.
amin
